source.name: City of Sydney
source.notes: Based on official City of Sydney recycling guidelines. Yellow-lid bin for recycling. No rinsing required. Polystyrene and soft plastics NOT accepted. Container Deposit Scheme (Return and Earn) for 10c refund on eligible bottles/cans.

materials.name: Aluminium cans
instructions: No need to rinse — just empty and dry
Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Eligible for 10c refund via Return and Earn (Container Deposit Scheme)
Do not crush — sorting machines identify shape
commonMistakes: Don't put cans inside plastic bags
Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Steel tins and cans
instructions: Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Includes food tins (baked beans, tomatoes, tuna, soup, etc.)
Steel cans are magnetically separated at the recycling facility
commonMistakes: Don't put sharp lids back inside the tin — press the lid down into the can
Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
notes: Only accepted when fully empty
Do not puncture or crush
commonMistakes: Don't put partially full aerosol cans in recycling — they are hazardous
Don't remove the nozzle

materials.name: Aluminium foil
instructions: Scrunch foil into a ball at least the size of a tennis ball
Keep adding to the ball over time
Place in the yellow-lid bin when large enough
notes: Small pieces fall through sorting machines — that's why scrunching into a ball is important
Must be free of food
commonMistakes: Don't put small flat pieces of foil in — scrunch them into a ball first
Don't include foil-lined packaging (e.g. chip packets) — that's not pure foil

materials.name: Glass bottles
notes: All colours of glass accepted
Many glass bottles are eligible for 10c Return and Earn refund
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap in newspaper and place in red-lid bin
Don't include window glass, mirrors, or pyrex

materials.name: Glass jars
notes: Metal lids can stay on — they are separated during processing
commonMistakes: Don't include ceramic or porcelain containers
Don't include candle jars with wax residue

materials.name: Soft drink bottles (plastic)
notes: Usually PET #1 plastic
Eligible for 10c Return and Earn refund
commonMistakes: Don't crush bottles — leave them intact for sorting
Don't put bottles inside plastic bags

materials.name: Water bottles (plastic)
notes: Eligible for 10c Return and Earn refund
Consider using a refillable bottle instead
commonMistakes: Don't put in a plastic bag — place loose in the bin

materials.name: Juice bottles (plastic)
notes: Eligible for 10c Return and Earn refund if under 1 litre
commonMistakes: Don't include juice boxes/tetra paks — they are NOT recyclable in Sydney

materials.name: Milk bottles (plastic)
notes: Usually HDPE #2 plastic
One of the most commonly recycled plastics
commonMistakes: Don't include milk cartons (Tetra Pak) — they are NOT recyclable in Sydney's yellow bin

materials.name: Plastic food containers and tubs
instructions: No need to rinse — just empty and dry
notes: Includes rigid plastic tubs and containers
NOT polystyrene — polystyrene foam containers go in trash
commonMistakes: Don't include polystyrene (styrofoam) containers
Don't include soft plastic lids or cling wrap

materials.name: Biscuit trays (plastic)
instructions: Empty and remove from outer packaging
notes: Rigid plastic trays from biscuit packets are recyclable
NOT polystyrene trays
commonMistakes: Don't include the soft plastic outer wrapper — that goes in the rubbish

materials.name: Plastic meat trays
instructions: No need to rinse — just empty
notes: Only rigid plastic trays — NOT polystyrene foam trays
Check the tray material — polystyrene trays go in rubbish
commonMistakes: Don't include polystyrene foam meat trays — they go in the red-lid bin
Don't include the cling wrap — that's soft plastic and goes in rubbish

materials.name: Fruit punnets
instructions: Remove any fruit or food scraps
notes: Clear rigid plastic punnets are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include the soft plastic film or netting that sometimes covers punnets

materials.name: Yoghurt tubs
notes: Rigid plastic yoghurt tubs are recyclable
Foil lids can be scrunched and added to your aluminium foil ball
commonMistakes: Don't include the foil lid loose — scrunch it into your foil ball

materials.name: Margarine and butter tubs
notes: Rigid plastic tubs are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include tubs with large amounts of product remaining

materials.name: Laundry detergent containers
notes: Usually HDPE #2 plastic — highly recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include if product remains inside
Don't include laundry pods packaging (soft plastic)

materials.name: Dishwashing liquid bottles
notes: Includes both hand dishwashing and dishwasher detergent bottles
commonMistakes: Don't include dishwasher tablet wrappers (soft plastic)

materials.name: Shampoo bottles
notes: Usually HDPE #2 plastic
commonMistakes: Don't include shampoo sachets (soft plastic)

materials.name: Conditioner bottles
notes: Same rules as shampoo bottles
commonMistakes: Don't include hair treatment sachets (soft plastic)

materials.name: Hand wash bottles
notes: Pump mechanism is recycled with the bottle
commonMistakes: Don't include hand wash refill pouches (soft plastic)

materials.name: Disinfectant and cleaning product bottles
notes: Trigger sprays are recyclable with the bottle
commonMistakes: Don't include cleaning wipes containers if they still contain wipes

materials.name: Newspapers
instructions: Remove any plastic wrapping first — wrapping goes in rubbish
Place newspapers loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: One of the most commonly recycled materials in Australia
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic wrapping
Don't bundle with string or rubber bands

materials.name: Magazines
notes: Glossy paper and staples are fine — no need to remove them
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic wrapping or plastic inserts

materials.name: Advertising and junk mail
notes: Glossy and coloured paper is fine
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic-wrapped bundles without removing the wrapping first

materials.name: Letters and envelopes
instructions: Window envelopes are OK — no need to remove the plastic window
notes: Plastic windows on envelopes are separated during processing
commonMistakes: Don't include padded or bubble-wrap envelopes — they go in rubbish

materials.name: Cardboard boxes
notes: Flatten boxes so they fit in the bin and don't blow away
Large boxes can be cut down to fit
commonMistakes: Don't include waxed cardboard (e.g. produce boxes from the market)
Don't include polystyrene or bubble wrap packing

materials.name: Egg cartons (cardboard)
notes: Cardboard egg cartons only — not polystyrene egg cartons
commonMistakes: Don't include polystyrene egg cartons — they go in the rubbish

materials.name: Pizza boxes
notes: Small amounts of grease are OK
Remove any plastic inserts or leftover pizza
commonMistakes: Don't include boxes soaked with grease or food — heavily soiled boxes go in rubbish

materials.name: Cereal boxes and food packaging boxes
notes: Thin cardboard/paperboard boxes are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic liner — it goes in rubbish

materials.name: Paper bags
notes: Brown and white paper bags are both accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include paper bags with plastic linings or foil linings

materials.name: Office paper and printer paper
notes: Shredded paper should be contained in a paper bag or cardboard box so it doesn't scatter
commonMistakes: Don't include laminated paper
Don't include paper with heavy glitter or foil

materials.name: Wrapping paper (non-metallic)
instructions: Remove any tape, ribbons, and bows
Scrunch test: if it stays scrunched, it's recyclable
notes: Only plain paper wrapping — not metallic, glittery, or plastic-coated
commonMistakes: Don't include metallic or glittery wrapping paper — it goes in rubbish
Don't include cellophane or plastic wrap

materials.name: Food scraps
instructions: Can be wrapped in newspaper or placed in a compostable liner
notes: All food scraps accepted: fruit, vegetables, meat, bones, dairy, bread, rice, pasta
Sydney's green bin accepts food AND garden waste together
commonMistakes: Don't put food scraps in the yellow-lid recycling bin — they contaminate recycling
Don't use plastic bags as liners — only newspaper or certified compostable bags

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable scraps
notes: All fruit and veg scraps accepted, including citrus and onion
commonMistakes: Don't put produce stickers in compost — peel them off first

materials.name: Meat and bones
notes: Sydney's green bin accepts all meat and bones
Commercial composting facility processes these at high temperatures
commonMistakes: Don't put meat in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Bread, pasta, and rice
notes: Cooked or uncooked — both are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic bread bag — that goes in rubbish

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Small amounts of liquid dairy can be absorbed with newspaper
notes: Accepted in Sydney's FOGO (Food Organics Garden Organics) green bin
commonMistakes: Don't pour large volumes of liquid milk into the bin

materials.name: Tea bags and coffee grounds
instructions: Place directly in the green-lid bin
notes: Most tea bags contain small amounts of plastic — they still go in the green bin for commercial composting
Coffee grounds are excellent for composting
commonMistakes: Don't include coffee capsules (e.g. Nespresso) — return them through the manufacturer's recycling program

materials.name: Garden waste
instructions: Cut large branches to fit inside the bin
notes: Branches should be under 30cm long and 10cm diameter to fit in the bin
commonMistakes: Don't include treated timber or painted wood
Don't include soil or rocks

materials.name: Flowers and garden prunings
instructions: Remove any plastic wrapping, string, or wire
notes: Cut down large stems to fit in the bin
commonMistakes: Don't include floral foam (oasis) — it's plastic and goes in rubbish

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
Or return to REDcycle collection bins at Coles/Woolworths (if available)
notes: Plastic bags jam sorting equipment at recycling facilities
NEVER put recyclables inside a plastic bag
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic bags in the yellow-lid recycling bin — they tangle in machinery

materials.name: Soft plastics and cling wrap
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: The 'scrunch test': if you scrunch it and it stays scrunched, it's soft plastic — goes in rubbish
REDcycle collections at some supermarkets (check availability)
commonMistakes: Don't put soft plastics in the yellow-lid bin — they jam machinery

materials.name: Polystyrene (styrofoam)
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: NOT accepted in Sydney's yellow-lid recycling bin
Includes foam cups, foam trays, foam packaging peanuts, and foam boxes
commonMistakes: Don't put polystyrene in the recycling bin — it contaminates the recycling stream

materials.name: Light globes (non-fluorescent)
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: NOT accepted in yellow-lid recycling bin
Fluorescent tubes and CFLs are hazardous — take to a drop-off point
commonMistakes: Don't put light globes in recycling — they break and contaminate glass recycling
Don't put fluorescent tubes in general waste — they contain mercury

materials.name: Mirrors
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: Mirror glass is coated and cannot be recycled with bottles and jars
commonMistakes: Don't put mirrors in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Window glass and sheet glass
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: Window glass is treated differently from bottle glass and cannot be recycled together
commonMistakes: Don't put window glass in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Crockery and ceramics
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling — never put in the yellow-lid bin
Donate intact items to op shops instead
commonMistakes: Don't put crockery or ceramics in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Drinking glasses and pyrex
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: Drinking glasses and heat-resistant glass (pyrex) have different melting points from bottle glass
They contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put drinking glasses or pyrex in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Tissues and napkins
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: Too contaminated and degraded to recycle
Can go in green-lid compost bin if your council allows — check City of Sydney guidelines
commonMistakes: Don't put tissues or napkins in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Paper towels
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: Paper towels are too degraded and contaminated to recycle
Paper towel tubes (cardboard) CAN be recycled in the yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put used paper towels in the yellow-lid recycling bin
Do recycle the empty cardboard tube

materials.name: Waxed cardboard
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: The wax coating prevents the cardboard from being recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put waxed cardboard in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: Disposable coffee cups have a plastic lining that makes them unrecyclable
Bring a reusable cup instead — most cafes offer a discount
commonMistakes: Don't put disposable coffee cups in recycling — the plastic lining means they can't be recycled

materials.name: Tetra Paks and liquid paperboard cartons
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: NOT accepted in Sydney's yellow-lid recycling bin
Made from layers of cardboard, plastic, and foil — difficult to recycle
commonMistakes: Don't put Tetra Paks in the yellow-lid bin — they are NOT accepted in Sydney

materials.name: Nappies and sanitary products
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: Cannot be recycled or composted
commonMistakes: Don't put nappies in recycling or compost bins

materials.name: Bioplastics and compostable plastics
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: NOT accepted in Sydney's yellow-lid recycling bin
NOT accepted in the green-lid compost bin either
Bioplastics contaminate both recycling and standard composting
commonMistakes: Don't put bioplastics in the recycling bin — they contaminate recycling
Don't put bioplastics in the green compost bin — council composting doesn't process them

materials.name: Chip packets, lolly wrappers, and snack packaging
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: Made from mixed materials (plastic and foil) — not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put foil-look wrappers in recycling — they are not aluminium foil

materials.name: Bubble wrap
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: Bubble wrap is a soft plastic and is not accepted in recycling
Consider reusing it before disposing
commonMistakes: Don't put bubble wrap in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Plastic straws, cutlery, and stirrers
instructions: Place in the red-lid general waste bin
notes: Too small and lightweight to be sorted at recycling facilities
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic cutlery in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do NOT place in any kerbside bin
Take to a battery recycling drop-off point
Tape the terminals of lithium batteries before transport
notes: Batteries can cause fires in rubbish trucks and recycling facilities
Drop-off at Officeworks, Aldi, Battery World, or council drop-off events
commonMistakes: NEVER put batteries in the red-lid or yellow-lid bin — fire risk

materials.name: Electronics and e-waste
instructions: Do NOT place in any kerbside bin
Take to a council e-waste drop-off event or collection point
notes: E-waste contains valuable materials that can be recovered
City of Sydney runs regular e-waste collection events
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in the red-lid bin — they contain hazardous materials

materials.name: Paint and household chemicals
instructions: Do NOT place in any kerbside bin
Take to a Community Recycling Centre (CRC)
Keep in original containers with labels
notes: City of Sydney residents can use the Juliett Street Community Recycling Centre
Never pour chemicals down the drain
commonMistakes: Never pour paint or chemicals down the drain or into the bin

materials.name: Sharps and needles
instructions: Place in an approved sharps container
Return full containers to a pharmacy or community health centre
Do NOT place loose in any bin
notes: Free sharps containers available from pharmacies
Never place loose sharps in any kerbside bin
commonMistakes: NEVER put loose needles or sharps in any bin — serious injury risk to workers

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes and CFL globes
instructions: Do NOT place in any kerbside bin
Take to a Community Recycling Centre (CRC)
notes: Contain small amounts of mercury
Handle carefully to avoid breakage
commonMistakes: Don't put fluorescent tubes in the red-lid or yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Motor oil and cooking oil
instructions: Do NOT pour down the drain
Take motor oil to a service station or Community Recycling Centre
Small amounts of cooking oil can be absorbed with newspaper and placed in red-lid bin
notes: Motor oil is recycled and re-refined
Never pour oil down the sink or storm drain
commonMistakes: Never pour oil down the drain — it pollutes waterways

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate wearable items to op shops (Vinnies, Salvos, Red Cross)
Unusable textiles can go in the red-lid bin as a last resort
notes: Do NOT put clothing in the yellow-lid recycling bin
Many charities accept worn or damaged textiles for recycling into rags or insulation
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing or textiles in the yellow-lid recycling bin

recycle: Aluminium and steel tins/cans (empty)
Empty aerosol cans
Aluminium foil (scrunched to tennis ball size)
Glass bottles and jars (lids and labels on)
Plastic bottles — soft drink, water, juice, milk (lids on)
Plastic food containers and tubs (no polystyrene)
Biscuit trays, fruit punnets, meat trays (rigid plastic only)
Cleaning product bottles — detergent, shampoo, hand wash, disinfectant (empty)
Newspapers, magazines, junk mail (remove plastic wrapping)
Letters and envelopes (window envelopes OK)
Cardboard boxes, egg cartons, pizza boxes (flatten, remove food)
compost: All food scraps (fruit, veg, meat, bones, dairy, bread, rice)
trash: Tetra Paks and liquid paperboard cartons

recycle: Plastic bags and soft plastics — jam sorting machinery
Polystyrene foam cups, trays, and packaging
Light globes, mirrors, and window glass
Crockery, drinking glasses, and pyrex
Tissues, napkins, and paper towels
Waxed cardboard, coffee cups, and Tetra Paks
Batteries, electronics, and sharps
Bioplastics and compostable plastics
Nappies and sanitary products
compost: Plastic bags (even 'biodegradable' ones unless certified compostable)

tips: No rinsing required — just empty and dry containers
Leave lids and labels on bottles and jars
Scrunch aluminium foil into a ball at least the size of a tennis ball
Flatten cardboard boxes to save space
Never bag your recyclables — place items loose in the yellow-lid bin
Use the Container Deposit Scheme (Return and Earn) for 10c refund on eligible containers
Polystyrene is NEVER recyclable in the yellow-lid bin
Soft plastic fails the 'scrunch test' — goes in rubbish, not recycling
When in doubt, put it in the red-lid bin — contamination ruins recycling
Batteries can cause fires — always take to a drop-off point

locations.name: Return and Earn (Container Deposit Scheme)
accepts: Eligible drink bottles and cans (10c refund)
locations.notes: Multiple locations across Sydney — find your nearest at returnandearn.org.au
